awd_abstract_narration:
Human cognitive abilities are certainly remarkable. Yet, studies on the cognition of other large-brained animals demonstrate that the cognitive abilities of humans are not exceptional. Rather, humans are just at the extreme end of the cognitive spectrum. As such, research on cognitive evolution in other large-brained primates can offer insight into the origin of human cognitive abilities. In this project, researchers will probe the breadth and depth of social cognition in arguably one of the “smartest” primates outside of apes and humans – white-faced capuchin monkeys. This project supports a unique field station where researchers have combined a diverse biological field site with an on-site environmental endocrinology laboratory and training facility for students. This combination of field site and laboratory offers a field school each year. Therefore the project supports numerous student training opportunities in STEM research and fosters an international network of scientific researchers and collaborative relationships. 

One of the leading hypotheses for explaining advanced primate intelligence is the "social complexity hypothesis." This is the idea that the challenges of living in large, complex social groups will select for animals with larger brains and greater cognition. However, current methods use “group size” as a proxy for social complexity, a variable that does not capture variation in social complexity for most primate species. By contrast, social knowledge – knowledge about the identity and relationships of other individuals – captures social complexity much better because it tracks the information animals use in their everyday lives. Importantly, the origin of large brains in capuchins is independent from that of apes, and thus capuchins offer a second event for researchers to identify selective pressures that led to large brains and sophisticated cognition. In this project, the researchers will examine what social knowledge capuchins have and how they use it day to day. Specifically, they will conduct playback experiments using vocal sequences to test whether white-faced capuchins understand the relative dominance ranks and kin relations of others in their group (“depth” of social knowledge) and whether they recognize and know the ranging patterns of others from neighboring groups (“breadth” of social knowledge). This program will provide data on one of the most important taxa for comparative analyses of primate cognition. The project is jointly supported by NSF's Biological Anthropology program and Behavioral Systems Cluster.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

 Our previous NSF provided essential support for our long-term study, allowing us to maintain and expand research on a novel population of white-faced capuchins in the Taboga Forest. The goals of this NSF were to understand the breadth and depth of social knowledge in capuchins, research that requires a library of recent (within the year), high-quality vocalizations from known individuals for use in playback experiments. While COVID set us back significantly (we had to evacuate our students, and when we returned nearly a year later, we had to collect a new library of vocalizations), we were able to recover our research program across 2021-2022. Our first playback experiment tested whether capuchin subjects recognize the vocalization of a simulated caller. For this experiment, we used food peeps, a common and non-threatening vocalization, played at a distance of 10-20 m to simulate the presence of particular individuals (N=48 trials). As predicted, subjects responded more strongly to the playback of an extra-group caller than a within-group caller, presumably because the close proximity of an extra-group individual is either surprising or threatening. We also found that females were somewhat less attentive to the difference between within-group and extra-group callers than males were. This suggests that males might be more attentive to extra-group information and females more attentive to within-group information, consistent with life history and behavioral differences in capuchins.

We published 5 manuscripts during the funding period. We documented the group ranges for our four habituated groups in addition to overall capuchin density, which is 2-6 times higher than for other capuchin sites [28]. Second, we validated measurements of neopterin from capuchin urine using both wild and captive capuchins [94]. As an indicator of inflammation, neopterin is one biomarker used to reflect overall health and well-being [95]. Third, we wrote two reviews using an “information perspective” to review how experimental manipulations in the wild help us understand animal cognition, with a focus on capuchins [96, 97]. Finally, we validated the measurement of four steroid hormones from capuchin fecal samples, reporting the lack of seasonal differences in glucocorticoids across seasons and age-related testosterone concentrations across males [54].

 

BROADER IMPACTS

In our first 6 years as a research project, we have demonstrated a strong record of student and research assistant mentoring and support. Internationally, we have trained 6 full-time Costa Rican field assistants and 1 Costa Rican manager; and we have mentored 8 graduate students (7/8 women, 2/8 Latinx, 2/8 LGBTQ+, 1/8 Black), 2 additional Costa Rican interns, 2 Costa Rican undergraduate senior theses, and 9 University of Michigan undergraduates on short-term research projects. We have additionally trained 19 field assistants (15/19 female; 2/19 Latinx; 2/19 LGBTQ+) in behavioral, acoustic, and endocrine methods. All Costa Rican research assistants attended the Animal Behavior Conference (Jul 2022, San José, Costa Rica) with 2 of them presenting our research in Spanish. Additionally, we sponsored one of our Costa Rican lab technicians to take a 2-year laboratory training course (Chemical-Clinical Lab Assistance, through the College of Microbiologists and Clinical Chemists of Costa Rica). All publications emerging from the site feature our Costa Rican collaborators and (where relevant) some of our international assistants as authors.

We routinely offer workshops (writing, research, conservation) to the academic community and educational programs (on behavior and ecology of primates) to the Costa Rican K-12 schoolchildren in the area. We donate our own time and resources to conservation efforts on the reserve including conservation cleanups (removal of garbage and industrial waste), restoring farmland to forest (purchasing and planting trees), and investing in flora and fauna monitoring projects (e.g., monitoring the invasive neem tree, monitoring all wildlife (using camera traps), and advising for one of the Biological Corridors, the Paso Del Mono Aullador Corridor (to connect the reserve where we work to the nearby Palo Verde National Park). As part of this, we have spent extensive time with UTN to develop a “master plan” for the site, which includes developing a philosophy dedicated to social and environmental justice, implementing sustainable practices on the experimental farm and the field station, and expanding the field station to be a leader in experimental field research.

Finally, we have improved the infrastructure at the Taboga field station to facilitate teaching and learning for the local community as well as internationally. This includes repairing 4 buildings (that can house ~20 researchers) and building an on-site endocrine laboratory. This on-site laboratory has already led to cross-site collaborations for capuchin research and is building marketable laboratory skills in our Costa Rican collaborators. Together with faculty member, Dr. Mónica Retamosa Izaguirre, a tropical bird expert from Instituto Internacional en Conservación y Manejo de Vida Silvestre, Universidad Nacional, Costa Rica, we are working to identify promising Costa Rican students who see themselves on a research track in behavioral ecology, endocrinology, and/or animal cognition.


Last Modified: 08/29/2023
Modified by: Jacinta C Beehner
